Purpose
This policy relates to the decontamination service provided by the Endoscope Decontamination Unit (EDU) to on site user departments at Mid Essex Hospitals Services NHS Trust (MEHT) from June nd
The EDU is to be operated in accordance with the standards reflected in BS EN ISO 13485, HTM 01-06, HTM 2030, and ISO 15883-4
The EDU sits within the Endoscopy Unit, in the Surgery Directorate
The Endoscopy Unit is located on level 3 of the PFI Building. Its entrance is at A301 with Theatres and Day Stay.

To ensure all flexible endoscopes are decontaminated in the EDU to meet requirements of national standards and legislation for the decontamination, maintenance and use of flexible endoscopes, and to comply with Health and Safety requirements relating to endoscopes [1,2, 3, 4, 5, 6].
This policy outlines the service level agreement between the EDU and the Departments to which it provides a service
The objective of this policy is ensure safe, efficient utilisation and provision of high quality Endoscopes for the service

It forms part of the requirements for Global Rating Scale (GRS) accreditation standards, the Joint Advisory Group (JAG) accreditation standards, and provides reference materials and guidance for all users of the Endoscopy service for nursing staff, endoscopists, and trainees.
This service is developed in line with recommendations from the following guidance:
Joint Advisory Group (JAG) and the Global Rating Scale (GRS);
NICE guidelines for endoscopes;
Health Act 2006;
HTM 01-06 guidelines.
Definitions used within the Policy:
EDU Endoscope Decontamination Unit; vCJD Variant Creutzfelt-Jakob Disease; AER Automatic Endoscopy Re-processor.
Aims of the Service
To provide a high quality decontamination service to all users of endoscopes within the Trust.
To ensure the out of hours service within the Trust e.g. Theatres, Urology Suite, GICU, Radiology and Endoscopy have the appropriate decontaminated scopes available for emergency procedures.
To comply with the relevant NICE guidelines, Joint advisory Group Guidelines and
Global Rating Scale audits to ensure that a high standard of decontamination is achieved for all scopes treated within the EDU, so that JAG accreditation can be maintained.
Scope of the Service
All flexible endoscopes will be decontaminated in EDU.
The EDU will be operational between Monday to Friday: 07:00 to 21:00 and Saturday and Sunday 07:00 to 17:30.

These hours may be revised at the discretion of the Head of Decontamination Services in order to take account of user activity and requirements. Users will be kept informed regarding any proposed changes.
On-call service will be in place and EDU personnel can be contacted via the switchboard. EDU may be operational at weekends and on bank holidays to decontaminate scopes for the next day's cases.

Routine turnaround times for endoscopes will be 4 hours. Where scopes need to be fast- tracked, the EDU will aim to process the scope within 2 hours. This assumes there are no process failures and that there are no other fast-track requests being dealt with at the same time. Scopes delivered to EDU after 17:30 hours may not be processed until the following day.
The EDU will implement and maintain a quality management system based on ISO 13485/ HTM 2030.

The EDU will develop, implement and maintain operational procedures for all aspects of its activities in relation to endoscopic reprocessing and collection and distribution of scopes. These procedures will also address the management responsibilities of the EDU including microbiological monitoring.
Maintain a customer complaints procedure via the Trust PALS and Complaints department. This information will advise regarding the action taken to prevent a re-occurrence of the problem.
Ensure decontamination matters are raised and discussed in decontamination, infection control, risk management, endoscopy user group, unit staff and governance meetings.
Ensure involvement from infection prevention and control department and a named microbiologist in managing and maintaining the service.
Ensure that detergents, disinfectants, endoscopes, washer/disinfectors, cabinets are used in accordance with manufacturer's guidelines.
Ensure compatibility of the scopes with the process equipment and chemicals used within the EDU, prior to processing.
Ensure scopes are tagged and identified at all stages of processing.

Ensure washer/disinfector and storage cabinets are cleaned, maintained, tested and validated according to manufacturer's guidance and the quality system standards applied by the EDU. Cleaning should be a minimum of once a week.
Maintenance, testing and validation records will be kept at EDU for the purpose of audit.
EDU is responsible for supplying scope covers.
Ensure spare scope buttons and bungs are decontaminated and sent to users at the beginning of each working day.
Ensure there is a policy in place for scopes used on CJD patients (refer to CJD infection control policy).
Ensure that any non-conformity is investigated and that effective corrective action is taken.
Staffing, Training & Education
EDU has a designated lead for Decontamination as defined in JAG requirements.
Skill mix for EDU/Endoscopy is based upon Trust/NMC Guidelines and in accordance with BSG Guidelines on staffing.
The Endoscopy Department manager is responsible for the overall efficiency of the department, supported by the Decontamination Lead.
Nurses trained in the decontamination processes of endoscopes will staff the reprocessing area.
All staff will adhere to BSG guideline and unit policies.
All staff to ensure compliance with up to date mandatory training as per mandatory training Policy and training needs analysis; register number 08092.
The EDU will ensure:
Staff wear appropriate Personal Protective Equipment when decontaminating and processing scopes.
COSHH risk assessments are carried out in accordance with the COSHH policy.
There is a procedure for spillages; chemicals, detergents, body fluids.
A spillage kit and eye wash station is available within the department.
The EDU Lead will ensure staff undertake competency based training in relation to the following:
Decontamination of different types of endoscopes;
Identification of individual endoscopes and all associated channels;
Design and function of endoscopes;
Decontamination process (assembly and dismantling of endoscopes, manual cleaning, accessories, disinfection, washer/disinfector, drying, storage, transportation, tracking/traceability);
Basic microbiology weekly testing;
General cleaning techniques for all equipment and surfaces in the EDU., and frequency of cleaning requirements;
Detergents and disinfectant;
Washer/disinfector-testing, validation and cleaning;
Storage cabinet-testing, validation and cleaning;
Health and safety;
COSHH training;
Training from manufactures on using of washer/disinfectors and storage cabinets;
Decontamination E-learning training package;
Current standards and legislations, including Top Ten Tips from MHRA.
Responsibilities
The Chief Operating Officer (COO) is operationally responsible for all decisions and/or changes made to the EDU.
The Associate Chief Nurse (ACN) for Surgery in conjunction with the Chief Operating Officer and Assistant Director of Operations for Surgery (ADO) are responsible for the Nursing staff present in EDU

Finance leads for EDU within the Endoscopy service sit within the Surgical Division, and liaise with the Clinical Lead (CL) for Endoscopy, Matron for Endoscopy and the EDU lead with the Senior Sister/Charge Nurse for Endoscopy.

The lead for EDU will work in conjunction with the Director of Infection Prevention and Control (DIPC) and be consulted in matters relating to Microbiology as appropriate to ensure high standards if infection Control are maintained.
The Head of Decontamination Services will be responsible for ensuring that the final water
quality is routinely tested in accordance with CFPP 0106/ HTM 2030 and he/she will appoint the services of an appropriate third party certified test laboratory to undertake this work.
Transportation of scopes between Clinical Departments and the EDU
5.6.1 Department staff or Porters will collect and deliver on daily basis according to the users demand. A Schedule has been agreed with each department.
5.6.2 Collection times 08.00 - 18.00. After 6pm scopes must be delivered to the EDU for decontamination by department staff. Scopes delivered after 17:30 may not be processed until the following day.

5.6.3 Scopes to be returned to the relevant departments by the end of each working day – unless the scope has been quarantined as non-conforming, in which case the user will be advised as soon as the matter is identified.
Contract facilities services
5.7.1 Ensuring EDTE in conjunction with EBME (estates and facilities) provide maintenance, testing and validation of equipment according to CFPP 0106 / HTM 2030.
5.7.2 Respond within 1 hour to breakdown of the decontamination equipment in EDU.
5.7.3 Contact manufacturer of the equipment if repairs cannot be completed within 24 hours.
5.7.4 Provide an on call service subject to contract e.g. Puricore: Monday – Friday 09.00-17.00 service, will attend within 6 hours of callout within these hours.
Flow and Process through EDU
Preparation by Users
Flushing of channels immediately after use at the bed/trolley side with an Enzymatic detergent;
Ensuring the scope and its accessories are placed in the dedicated collection trolley, together with all connections and relevant data to permit traceability.
Collection
EDU will collect used scopes from each department using designated collection trolleys;
Trolleys will not be left unattended.
Manual cleaning
Single use cleaning devices will be used for manual cleaning
Scopes will be visually checked for obvious damage
Valves and detachable distal tips to be removed
Scope to be leak-tested
If the scope passes the leak test it will be manually cleaned.

If the scope fails the leak test it will be manually cleaned using a non-immersion method (i.e. wiped with an enzymatic detergent solution, then subsequently wiped with a damp cloth soaked in clean rinse water and manually dried) and returned to user for service/repair. If the scope is only socially cleaned it must be placed in a plastic bag before placing in the case for transportation. The manufacturer must be aware of this before return.
All accessories will be kept together with scope.
All channels will be brushed according to scopes manufacturer instructions.
Automated wash/disinfection
Each washer will be checked at the beginning of each day, that it has completed its disinfection cycle and that it complies with the relevant daily checklist checks;
The water pressure gauges will be checked each morning for the relevant water pressure between 3 – Bar;
Scope and accessories will be placed in washer/disinfector;
All channels will be connected for irrigation to the AER;
Only one AER cycle available for use;
If the cycle is successful scope will either be returned to user for use within 3 hours or placed in a storage cabinet for up to  days;

If the cycle fails the problem will be identified and the scope either reprocessed or the machine checked by an engineer – whichever is appropriate. If the scope if required for immediate use, the user will be informed. The fail slip will be kept in a log book for audit purposes;
A traceability label will be issued with all processed scopes. It is the user's responsibility to record the time the scope is used for tracking purposes;
Any faults with any washer will be documented in the log book with the relevant fault printout, and Buoyues, EBME and the Matron for Endoscopy informed of the fault.
Storage
Scopes to be protected from external contamination.
Scopes are transferred from the EDU in designated trolleys.
Traceability labels to be attached with scope.
Any non-conformity in testing will be communicated to users and agreed actions will be taken.
Scopes for adult and paediatric outpatients department will always be kept in the EDU storage cabinets.
EDU is responsible for daily check of storage cabinets and maintaining the logbook.
EDU in conjunction with EBME are responsible for maintenance, testing and validation (quarterly, annually).
Delivery
6.7.1 Delivery will be on regular basis by EDU porters.
6.7.2 Endoscopes will be delivered to departments according to daily requests/agreements.
Tracking of scopes
6.8.1 All scopes are to be tagged with a unique identifier in order to permit traceability to product history (i.e. to processes and patients).
6.8.2 Scopes are tagged in to the WD and storage cabinets.

6.8.3 Each scope will be labelled with the date and time of processing in order to identify whether the scope is within the stated shelf-life and suitable for immediate use .It is the user's responsibility to record the time of use on the patient label. If removed from the storage cabinet the scope must be used within 3 hours or reprocessed.
Key Relationships
Key Operational Requirements (Map of department within rd floor - appendix 1)
Endoscopy Reception;
Pre-assessment rooms with access to telephones and ICT;
Work bases for administrative staff, consultants, nurses, endoscopists;
Staff rest room within theatres;
Staff changing rooms male/female with toileting facilities and shower within theatres;
Endoscopy rooms x 3 (rooms 1,2 & 3);
EDU consisting of a separated clean and dirty room;
Storage facilities for:
Equipment;
Supplies;
Consumables;
Disposables.
Key Relationship with other Departments
Radiology;
GICU;
Urology;
Theatres;
Pharmacy;
Maintenance personnel (Buoyes/EBME).
Key Requirements for Facilities Management (F.M.)
7.3.1 Fire risk assessments, review by the Fire Officer and method of access in fire drill/alarm annually.
7.3.2 Pharmacy supplies will be supplied on a “topping up” basis other than for scheduled and dangerous drugs which will be supplied on a direct requisition basis.
7.3.3 All items for disposal will be taken to a designated Disposal Room off the endoscopy reception corridor, in accordance with Trust Waste Policy.
7.3.4 Housekeeping
Cleaning will be provided Monday to Sunday between 18.00 and 21.00 and will be checked in accordance with trust policy.
Cleaning of AERs is the responsibility of the decontamination room staff on a daily basis.
Cleaning of the Drying cabinets is the responsibility of the decontamination room staff on a weekly basis, unless it becomes dirty and requires more than weekly cleaning.
7.3.5 Portering
The portering department will undertake patient movement duties, collection and delivery services and any other ad hoc duties as requested.
7.3.6 Security services will be provided in line with Trust security policy.
7.3.7 Estates staff will undertake routine maintenance services, certain items of planned preventative maintenance on a cyclical basis and other ad hoc maintenance initiated on a requisition basis.
7.3.8 Materials management
A topping up service for all Supplies will be available to agreed levels:
Top up system provided by procurement management;
Weekly restocking of shelves from stock items;
Non stock items- ordering of non-stock items on an as and when needed basis from relevant suppliers via procurement and goods receiving.
7.3.9 EBME will provide a service for certain items as agreed, within the Service Level Agreement (SLA). Other items will be maintained by warranty/maintenance agreements.
7.3.10 EBME will hold spare keys to the EDU machinery and all endoscopy rooms, a spare set of keys will also be left at switchboard after hours.
Environmental Requirements
The EDU is within the Endoscopy department, located on level 3 of the PFI Building. Follow signs to A301 for Theatres/ Day Stay and Endoscopy.

The Decontamination room has a separated dirty/clean flow. The entrance for dirty scopes is adjacent to room 3 in Endoscopy. Scopes go through the washers and are stored in the clean decontamination area adjacent to theatres entrance.
Dirty scope trays are covered with red plastic covers and green sterile scope trays are covered with green covers to ensure no cross contamination between scope trays.
The Endoscopy Unit has air conditioning, similar to that in theatres and has been deemed safe and policy adherent by the Infection Prevention team. This is checked annually.

Water sampling of the three AER's are taken weekly at noon to be sent to an external laboratory for TVC and conductivity. These samples must meet the CFPP0106/ HTM 2030 guidelines, and meet the traffic light system in accordance with the infection prevention guidelines of our Trust. (Refer to appendix 2)
Decoration and colour scheme for clinical areas should be in line with Trust corporate approach but must be open and friendly for users.
Decontamination rooms as per Health Tendering Notes (HTNs) and Health Building Notes (HBNs).
Endoscopy Staff change in theatre changing rooms/or in the ward staff changing room.

Infection Prevention team will meet with the decontamination lead and unit manager or Matron to conduct an annual infection prevention audit of the decontamination room and also the whole Endoscopy unit.

The external lead for decontamination (Peter Rust) will meet with the unit manager and Matron for endoscopy annually to conduct an official external review of the decontamination service within the endoscopy unit, to be submitted for JAG review annually to maintain accreditation.
Security Requirements
8.11.1 The safety of patients and staff within the endoscopy department must be paramount at all times.
8.11.2 In the event of a fire call 2999 and for security 6666.
Fire Safety

8.12.1 The service will be compliant with the Trust's Fire Safety Policy, Fire Evacuation Policy and other local fire plans and procedures.” (The detail of these items will then be developed as part of the separate Fire Safety Work Programme, as led by the Trust's Fire Officer.)
ICT Requirements
The Endoscopy department and administration team will require access to computers, printers and the following hospital based facilities:
Lorenzo;
Infloflex;
PACS;
MEHT Review;
Tomcat;
Theatreman;
Unisoft - Endoscopic reports and images;
Email;
Internet.
N.B Other systems may be needed and these above are for illustrative purposes.
Tracking of scopes used per procedure /patient for infection control and as required for JAG registration.
Telephones.
Fax and photocopying.
Equipment Requirements
The following equipment is required in the EDU:
Endoscopes/ Bronchoscopes/Gastroscopes/Colonoscopes/EUS scopes/ Duodenoscopes;
Scope storage cupboards with forced filtered air;
Associated processors/ lightsources / screens;
AER washer disinfectors to latest specifications;
ICT equipment as stated in 9.0;
Changing rooms for staff;
Storage rooms for consumables/Linen;
Disposal rooms for waste.
Information Security
Patient identifiable data or sensitive data must never be emailed out of the Trust unless the information is encrypted or sent from and to an nhs.net account.
Patient information must never be downloaded onto any unencrypted mobile device.
All routine sharing of patient information must be agreed with a signed Data Sharing Agreement.
All staff must adhere to all the IT security and information governance policies listed in the Information Governance Handbook given to each member of staff individually.
All scopes are traced from their washing process to their use on each patient through the unit, and their subsequent return to the washers for re-decontamination.
Any breaches in the tracking of scopes must be recorded on the Trust datix system and investigated appropriately.
Contingency
Cabinets
In the event that a cabinet is out of use, the scopes will be stored in another cabinet. (There are drying cabinets kept in the urology suite and theatres).
Washer/disinfectors (AER)
The EDU has allowed sufficient throughput capacity to deal with the impact of one of its
AER not being available for use i.e. due to repair/ maintenance. In the event that two AER's not being available for use, the EDU could extend its working hours.
Service Failure
12.3.1 In the event that the EDU cannot run its machines due to a service failure e.g. water, the Head of Decontamination Services would immediately inform all relevant Clinical
departments in order that plans can be put in place to re-schedule patient procedures and to seek off-site processing.
12.3.2 Service, repairs and replacement programme for endoscopes are the Clinical Lead for Endoscopy/Assistant Chief Executive for Medicine's responsibility.
12.3.3 Ensuring agreement is in place with EBME for service, maintenance and repairs of all scopes.
12.3.4 Ensuring replacement programme is in place for old, obsolete items.
Contact Details
In the event of an incident the service would refer to the Trust incident policy suite and the Business continuity policy.
In the event of the decontamination room having equipment failure and being unable to provide – disinfected scopes, no endoscope will be used in a body cavity.
In the event of the computer system not being available for results the relevant department would be contacted by phone.
In the event of the Trust telephone system being unavailable, Trust policy regarding internal incident or business continuity would be followed.

In the event of a shortage of specialist staff able to carry out the relevant procedures, temporary staff allocated by the Staff Bank or another outside agency will be requested to backfill these shortages. Where this is not possible, endoscopy lists may be lost or re- arranged for alternative sessions or dates.
In the event of IT failure, paper documentation is completed and uploaded when IT systems are re-established.
Auditing this Policy

The EDU service will be subjected to internal audits which form an integral part of the Quality Management System. Third party certification is to be sought in line with the requirements of BS EN ISO 13485 within the first 12 months of the unit being operational. It will be audited quarterly by an external company and annually by a certification body.

Breaches of this policy will be reported via the datix system, where trends can be identified and brought to the attention of the management and clinical stakeholders. This will include failure/breakdown of equipment impairing service delivery, management of staff sickness and resultant treatment capacity deficits.
Patient Safety and Quality Committee will be supplied with datix trend data, and incidents requiring immediate assessment will be fed back directly.

Endoscopy User Group meetings held monthly with all staff, management and clinical stakeholders represented. The aim of these meetings is to share best practice, shape service development and actively monitor risks and performance and feed directly in to the Service.
EDU as part of the Endoscopy unit will attend the monthly Governance meetings for theatres/anaesthetics to ensure all areas of audit, safety, and Governance are discussed.

Auditing of the Endoscopy department via JAG, GRS, CQC and MEHT Infection prevention policies, ensures that this department reaches the necessary requirements for the relevant accreditation and standards of practice.
Equality Impact Assessment
Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
